metadata.title: Reaction Cycles of Halogen Species in the Immune Defense: Implications for Human Health and Diseases and the Pathology and Treatment of COVID19

abstract.text: There is no vaccine or specific antiviral treatment for COVID19 that is causing a global pandemic. One current focus is drug repurposing research, but those drugs have limited therapeutic efficacies and known adverse effects. The pathology of COVID19 is essentially unknow. Without this understanding, it is challenging to discover a successful treatment to be approved for clinical use. This paper addresses several key biological processes of reactive oxygen, halogen and nitrogen species (ROS, RHS and RNS) that play crucial physiological roles in biosystems from plants to humans. It includes why superoxide dismutases, the enzymes to catalyze the formation of H2O2, are required for protecting ROS-induced injury in cell metabolism, why the amount of ROS/RNS produced by ionizing radiation at clinically relevant doses is ~1000 fold lower than the endogenous ROS/RNS level routinely produced in the cell, and why a low level of endogenous RHS plays a crucial role in the innate immune defense. Here we propose a striking yet plausible amplification mechanism in the immune defense: ozone-depleting-like halogen cyclic reactions enhancing RHS effects are responsible for all the mentioned physiological functions, which are activated by H2O2 and deactivated by NO signaling molecule. Our estimated results show that the reaction cycles can be repeated thousands of times and amplify the RHS pathogen-killing (defense) effects by 10 5 folds, resembling the cyclic O3-depleting reactions in the stratosphere. It is unraveled that H2O2 is a required protective signaling molecule (angel) in the defense system for human health and its dysfunction can cause many diseases such as autoimmune disorders, multiple organ failure, aging and cancer. We also identify a class of potent drugs for effective treatment of invading pathogens (COVID19), cancer and other diseases, and provide a molecular mechanism of action of the drugs or candidates.

Reactive oxygen species (ROS), including superoxide (O2 − ), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and hydroxyl radical (OH  ), are constantly produced from aerobic metabolism of the cell. It is known that OH  is potent but non-selective oxidant, while O2 − and H2O2 are far less reactive. Moreover, increasing evidence has showed that H2O2 is a necessary signaling molecule ('evil') in the regulation of a variety of biological processes such as cell proliferation and differentiation, tissue repair, immune cell activation, circadian rhythm, vascular remodeling and aging 1-5 . H2O2 is also a signaling molecule of plant defense against pathogens 6 .

body_text.text: Rising Evidence has also clearly demonstrated the critical physiological role of superoxide dismutases (SOD) in humans and all other mammals, which are the enzymes converting O2 − into H2O2 7 . For instance, it was observed that genetic knockout of SOD produced deleterious phenotypes in organisms ranging from bacteria to mice [8] [9] [10] [11] . Knockout mice lacking Mn-SOD died soon after birth or suffered severe neurodegeneration 8 . Mn-SOD was also shown to be required for protecting ROS-induced injury in O2 metabolism 11 . Mice lacking cytosolic Cu,Zn-SOD developed multiple pathologies, including liver cancer 9 , muscle atrophy, cataracts, and a reduced lifespan 10 . Research on biological action of ionizing radiation (IR) also showed that modifying SOD activity in bacteria reduced the oxygen radiosensitizing effect and that SOD injection following whole body x-irradiation significantly protected Swiss mice from lethality 12, 13 . Also, active SOD or SOD mimic compounds inhibited IR-induced deleterious effects including transformation assays, bystander effects, normal tissue damage associated with inflammatory responses and fibrosis 14, 15 . These studies clearly demonstrated that O2 − was somehow participating in radiation-induced injury, whereas H2O2 (SOD) was required for normal physiological functions. Given that O2 − is a weak oxidant and the downstream formation of OH  from H2O2 is highly reactive to cause oxidative damage, the precise role of H2O2 (or O2 − ) in these critical physiological functions is essentially unknown 15 .

Respiratory burst is the rapid release of reactive species from different types of cells. It is usually utilised for immunological defence. The exposure to ROS or reactive halogen species (RHS) or reactive nitrogen species (RNS) kills the engulfed pathogens, resulting in pathology of infection. Similar 'respiratory bust' is also found when cells are exposed to IR at a clinical radiation dose 15 or when the ozone layer is exposed to ionizing cosmic rays in the polar stratosphere especially with the presence of halogenated molecules (particularly freons, CFCs) [16] [17] [18] [19] .

Respiratory burst occurs mainly in phagocytes such as neutrophils, monocytes, macrophages, mast cells, and dendritic cells. Phagocytosis is the process by which a cell uses its plasma membrane to engulf a pathogen, forming an organelle called phagosome. It plays a major role in the innate immune defense by effectively killing of pathogens. The phagosome then moves toward the centrosome of the phagocyte and fuses with lysosomes, forming a phagolysosome for degradation of pathogens. A phagocyte has various receptors on its surface, including opsonin, scavenger and Toll-like receptors. For example, opsonin receptors increase the phagocytosis of pathogens coated with the Fc part of immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies or with complement. The widely accepted belief is that phagocytosis is most effective for killing bacteria, while the adaptive immune defense, mainly by lymphocytes, is more important for viral infections. However, increasing evidence has shown that phagocytosis plays a crucial role in killing a variety of intracellular or cytoplasmic viruses ranging from influenza, mumps, measles and rhinovirus to Ebola and HIV [20] [21] [22] [23] [24] [25] [26] [27] . Some studies showed that phagocytes directly protect against viral infections 20-23 , while others indicated that the antibody-dependent cellular phagocytosis provides mechanisms for clearance of virus and virus-infected cells and for stimulation of downstream adaptive immune responses by antigen presentation or the secretion of inflammatory mediators [24] [25] [26] . Phagocytes play also a crucial role in removing dead and dying cells including virus-infected cells killed by lymphocytes, which otherwise often cause autoimmune disorders.

For O2-dependent degradation in phagocytosis, it depends the production of ROS, RHS and RNS, as shown in Fig. 1 . First, the NADPH oxidases (NOX2) embedded in the phagolysosome membrane is activated to produce O2 − by O2 capturing an electron from cytosolic NADPH. H2O2 is generated from O2 − via superoxide dismutases (SOD) or heme(halo)peroxidases (MPO and EPO); OH  is then generated via the Haber-Weiss reaction. Through MPO/EPO, H2O2 activates a halogenating system, which generates hypochlorous acid (HOCl) and kills pathogens [27] [28] [29] [30] [31] . The inducible nitric oxide synthases (iNOS) also catalyze the production of NO  from L-arginine; NO  then reacts with O2 − to produce a peroxynitrite (ONOO − ) that forms NO2 (via reaction with CO2) [32] [33] [34] . The last reaction competes obviously with the SOD-catalyzed scavenging of O2 − .

All OH • , HOCl and ONOO − (NO2) are strong oxidants believed to cause damages in DNA/RNA and proteins and anti-pathogen effects [27] [28] [29] [30] [31] [32] [33] [34] . Particularly HOCl has widely been used as a strong disinfectant [27] [28] [29] [30] [31] ; HOBr and HOI at lower levels were also detected in stimulated immune cells (leukocytes) 28, 30 . Macrophages have weaker antiviral properties than neutrophils and their activation is made by transient respiratory burst, which regulates the inflammatory response by inducing synthesis of cytokines for redox signalling. Due to the high toxicity of ROS/RHS/RNS, damage to host tissues can also occur during inflammation. Of particular interest is the role of endogenous RHS in the O2-dependent killing mechanisms of invading pathogens. In fact, HOXs (X=Cl, Br) are important halogen species causing O3 depletion in the Earth's stratosphere 35, 36 . They are derived from solar photolysis 37 or cosmic-ray driven dissociative-electron-transfer (DET) reactions [16] [17] [18] [19] of halogenated organic molecules, especially CFCs. In radiobiology, there is also a long mystery that the amount of primary ROS produced by IR at clinically relevant radiation doses (2Gy) is ~1000 fold lower than the background (endogenous) ROS level produced by oxidative metabolism of the cell, as first noted by Ward in 1994 38 . This leads to the question of how the ROS produced by the few primary ionization events is amplified to account for observed biological effects. The mechanism remains elusive, as reviewed by Lehnert. 15 This gives a vivid reminder of the 1970s when atmospheric scientists were curious to hypothesize that significant ozone loss might result in the Earth's stratosphere, giving birth of modern ozone depletion theory. An amplifying mechanism is now well established that a Cl atom can catalytically destroy up to 10 5 O3 molecules via halogen reaction cycles 35 . Note also that during respiratory burst, the increases in O2 (not NO  ) consumption were typically observed to be 2-20 folds only among different cells and/or conditions 39 . This, together with the mysterious critical physiological role of H2O2, implies that a drastic amplification mechanism is clearly required.

Here we propose that (i) the initial yields of endogenous ROS/RHS/RNS produced in the phagosome are not sufficient to cause a significant anti-pathogen effect in the innate immune defense, for which an amplification mechanism is required; (ii) The O3-depleting-like reaction cycles of RHS take place in the phagosome for immunological defence in cells of humans and all other mammals, with the presence of enzymes such as hemeperoxidases or other antioxidant enzymes instead of solar photons or cosmic rays; (iii) Similar to the formation of polar O3 hole, numerous reaction cycles of RHS (mainly X  , XO  , HOX, OX − , X2; X=Cl or Br or I) play a major role in killing pathogens and immunological defence. These are schematically shown in Fig. 2 . Proposed halogen reaction cycles involved in the immune defense against pathogens and in the inflammatory process. The amplified reactions of reactive halogen species (RHS), including HOX, OX − , X 2 , X • and OX • (X=Cl, Br or I), produced by dissociative electron transfer (DET) within the phagosome cause major damage (represented by RX/RNX) to the DNA/RNA/lipids/proteins of phagocytosed pathogens. The innate immune defence system consists mainly of three components: the H 2 O 2 signaling pathway as the activator ('trigger'), the RHS reaction cycles as the 'accelerator' ('amplifier'), and the NO • signaling pathway as the deactivator ('terminator'). H 2 O 2 from other intracellular organelles such as mitochondria and peroxisomes can also diffuse across membranes and promote the anti-pathogen activity. 9 36 In biological systems, the halogenation of organic molecules is catalyzed by enzymes haloperoxidases such as MPO, EPO and LPO in normal physiological processes, which combine the inorganic substrates X − and H2O2 to produce RHS. RHS in turn oxidize the hydro-carbon ornitrogen substrate RH/RNH to synthesize many halogenated organic compounds (RX/RNX):
body_text.section: Proposal of reaction cycles of reactive halogen species (RHS)

body_text.text: Many halogenated organic compounds are biosynthesized via reaction (1). It is also well known that halogenated RX/RNX are highly effective for dissociative-electron-transfer (DET) reactions that result in anions R − /RN − /X − or reactive radicals X  /OX  /R  /RN 15,18,19,40-49 . As shown in Table  1 , all of these RHS have been found in biological systems especially phagosomes [27] [28] [29] [30] [31] [40] [41] [42] [43] [44] . One should be cautious with some reaction rate constants listed in Table 1 as they are somewhat outdated. For example, most experiments by nanosecond-or picosecond-resolved radiolysis of aqueous halogenated molecules actually measured the DET with the hydrated electron (eaq − ) rather than the subpicosecond-lived prehydrated electron (epre − ). eaq − is deeply bound at ~3.5 eV and is relatively inert, while epre − has a small binding energy of 1.0-1.5 eV and is extremely effective for DET with halogenated molecules, as well demonstrated and reviewed previously [46] [47] [48] [49] [50] [51] 18, 19 .
body_text.section: Proposal of reaction cycles of reactive halogen species (RHS)

body_text.text: Reactions (1) and (2) lay the solid foundation for halogen cyclic reactions to be presented below. Notably, the standard reduction potentials at pH 7 of all redox couples of the peroxidase cycle of enzymes MPO/EPO/LPO abundant in phagosomes are relatively small, being 0.8-1.3 V 28,30 , where RHS have generally large electron affinities. This means that the catalyzed cyclic reactions of RHS can readily take place and sustain for numerous cycles in the cell with those endogenous enzymes replacing solar photons or cosmic-ray-produced electrons. This is analogous to the established O3 depleting cyclic reactions. For example, X  and HOX with X=Cl, Br, or I can have the following cyclic reactions (bold represents altered targets such as damaged DNA/RNA/proteins): Note that cycle 1 including reactions (3a-3b and 3d-3f) or (4a-4b and 4d-4f) depends on H2O2, whereas cycle 2 including reactions (3a-3c and 3g-3j) or (4a-4c and 4g-4j) are H2O2 independent due to the DET of RN1X into a X  atom. In any case, however, the net effects of the above reaction cycles are the alternations (damages) of at least two biological targets R1NH and R2NH without consuming any halogen. Similar reaction cycles can also occur for other RHS such as XO  and X2. They are most effective (i.e., cycle 2 occurs), if the X  atom is yielded, which was indeed observed for radiolysis of N-bromoimides but not for N-chloroimides 42, 43 . Cycle 2 will be more significant with the formation of X2 in reaction (1) (as X2 + e −  X  + X − readily), and therefore will become dominant as the halogen level reaches above a threshold. Indeed, X2 was observed 40, 41 . Cycles 1 and 2 are expected to continue for numerous cycles before they are terminated. Note that the peroxidase cycle [28] [29] [30] [31] in catalyzing the reaction (X − +H2O2  HOX+ H2O) and the radical chain 42, 43 in radiolysis of N-halogenated species (R  +Br2RBr+Br  ; Br  +RHH + +Br − +R  . Net: Br2+RHRBr+Br − +H + ) have been proposed previously to enhance the reaction efficiency, but each of those cycles occurs at the consumption of a halogen species. They are therefore distinct from the O3-depleting-like halogen reaction cycles proposed here that have no cost of halogens (acting as 'catalysts'). Then a question arises: how would the halogen reaction cycles be terminated?
body_text.section: Proposal of reaction cycles of reactive halogen species (RHS)

body_text.text: In atmospheric photochemistry of ozone loss, RHS is removed from the catalytic cycles once the reaction ends with HX or XONO2 ("inactive reservoirs") 35, 36 . In the phagosome (cell), however, this would not be the case as aqueous HCl can readily react with OH  /HOX to form X  /X2 and the hydrolysis of XONO2 will quickly occur to form XO  and NO2. It should be noted that the above proposed cyclic reactions are essentially enzyme-driven electron-transfer reactions. Peroxynitrite has a half life of 1.9 s at pH 7.4 and its decomposition leads to a major product nitrate (NO3 − ) and a minor product of CO3 − or NO2 with/without reaction with CO2 32,33 :
body_text.section: Proposal of reaction cycles of reactive halogen species (RHS)

body_text.text: Since the redox potential of NO2 is close to that OH  , ONOO − is believed to act as an OH  -like oxidizing species in causing damaging effects 32, 33 . Notably, NO3 − is known to be an extremely effective scavenger for weakly-bound electrons (NO3 has an electron affinity of 3.94 eV, larger than any halogen) 47, 49, 50 , as we measured the reaction rate constant being as large as 1.2(±0.5)×10 13 M −1 s −1 . 50 Reaction of CO3 − with electrons or O2 − is also expected (see Table 1 ). Thus, the halogen reaction cycles would be terminated if there is a significant amount of NO3 − or CO3 − (mainly NO3 − ) in the phagosome. Remarkably, the reduction or removal of nitrogen species (HNO3 as the ultimate product) is a critical requirement for the formation of the ozone hole (significant ozone loss) in the polar stratosphere 35 It is very instructive to compare the negative ion chemistry in the Earth's stratosphere and troposphere and that in phagosome, as shown in Fig. 3 . Both are quite similar, involving identical species of O2 − , CO2, NO, NO2, and ONOO − , except for O3 absent in the cell 19, 52, 53 . For negative ion chemistry in the atmosphere, the primary ions are quickly converted into CO3 − (H2O)n ions on the order of 10 −3 s by a series of reactions with O2, CO2, O3 and H2O 52, 53 . In the undisturbed stratosphere, the CO3 − (H2O)n ions are converted relatively slowly into the more stable ions NO3 − (H2O)n or NO3 − (HNO3)m(H2O)n on the order of 1s by reaction with the trace gases NO, NO2, HNO3, and N2O5 52, 53 . For altitudes below 30 km, the hydrated NO3 − ions are the dominant and terminal species. The positive-ion chemistry is even simpler and the cluster ions H3O + (H2O)n (n=3-6) are the sole primary ions since their formation is also rapid (10 −3 s). This is much shorter than the (positive) ion-(negative) ion recombination lifetime (i.e., the residence time of ions) of approximately 100-1000 s in the atmosphere 53 .
body_text.section: Proposal of reaction cycles of reactive halogen species (RHS)

body_text.text: Looking into the rate constants in Table 1 and reactant abundances of all the cyclic reactions (1-5), we can see that reaction (1) or (3f) or (4f) is the rate-determining step, that is, the haloperoxidase catalyzed converting reaction of X − and H2O2 into HOX is the rate-limiting reaction. We further notice that H2O2 is very stable, while the lifetime of negative ions including Cl − /Br − /I − and NO3 − is controlled by the recombination time with the abundant hydronium ions H3O + (H2O)n in the acidic phagolysosome, which are long-lived (expected to be ≥100 s), in contrast to hydronium in neutral solutions. This is very similar for both the lower atmosphere and the phagolysosome. Given the Cl − and Br − concentrations in phagocytes are 120 mM (mean) and 60 µM (mean) 44 and the rate constants of 3.1×10 3 -2.5×10 4 M -1 s -1 and 1.1×10 6 -1.9×10 7 M -1 s -1 for the converting reaction with H2O2 respectively 28, 30 , we calculate that the overall Cl and Br cyclic reactions occur with respective rates of approximately 360-3000 s -1 and 66-1140 s -1 . These give rise to 3.6×10 4 -3×10 5 and 6.6×10 3 -1.1×10 5 reaction cycles during the lifetime of Cl − and Br − in the phagolysosome respectively. These estimated values, fairly close to the ozone depleting reaction cycles in the atmosphere 35 , appear quite striking, but they are determined by the levels of Cl − and Br − and the ion residence time. The latter is governed by the recombination with H3O + (H2O)n and is apparently quite similar in the stratosphere and in the phagolysosome.
body_text.section: Proposal of reaction cycles of reactive halogen species (RHS)

body_text.text: It follows that our proposed immune defence system fighting against pathogens is composed of three components: the H2O2 signaling pathway is the activator (trigger), the RHS reaction cycles the accelerator ('amplifier'), and the NO  signaling pathway (NO3 − ) the deactivator ('terminator') of RHS reactions, as shown in Fig. 2 . A delicate balance between these two important regulations by H2O2 and NO  is responsible for immunity that keeps the balanced state of multicellular organisms having adequate biological defenses to fight infection, disease, or other unwanted biological invasion, while having adequate tolerance to avoid allergy and autoimmune diseases/disorders. Note that as stable and small neutral signaling molecules that can diffuse easily across the membrane, both H2O2 and NO  from other cellular organelles such as peroxisomes and mitochondria can also involve in the defense system 54 .
body_text.section: Proposal of reaction cycles of reactive halogen species (RHS)

body_text.text: Given the abundances and low reduction potentials 28,30 of endogenous haloperoxidases (MPO/EPO/LPO) in phagosomes and the high resemblance 19,52,53 of the negative ion chemistry in phagosome to that in the atmosphere, it is very reasonable to find that the reaction cycles can be repeated thousands of times and amplify the RHS pathogen-killing (defense) effects by 10 4 -10 5 folds, analogous to the cyclic O3-depleting reactions 35 . For the latter, RHS is known to be far more efficient than OH and NO at catalyzing the destruction of ozone, and among RHS, Br or I is much more efficient than Cl at catalyzing the cyclic reactions 35, 36 . This proposed mechanism has multifold significance. 1) The H2O2-initiated halogen cyclic reactions should greatly amplify the pathogen-killing effects of RHS in the phagosome. It might lead to discoveries or identification of highly effective antiviral drugs to kill various viruses including severely aggressive viruses like current COVID19. 2) It also provides a long-sought amplification mechanism for reactive radicals produced by IR to generate significant radiobiological effects in human body, as compared with background ROS. 3) It reveals that H2O2 as a signaling molecule plays the key protective (pathogen-killing) role in immunological defence in many organisms from plants and animals to humans. 4) It also unravels the crucial physiological role of H2O2 to account for the observed critical effect of enzymes SOD [8] [9] [10] [11] [12] [13] [14] [15] . Once the SOD was impaired, the dysfunction of H2O2 as the protective molecule in the immune system resulted in and the animals died quickly.
body_text.section: It must be noted that the proposal of halogen reaction cycles in phagosomes appears striking and novel, but each of the reactions (1-5) is very well-grounded in the literature.

body_text.text: If people infected by an acute pathogen like COVID19 show mild and moderate symptoms and receive no or improper treatment, they might rapidly develop into severe cases of extreme respiratory burst. In the latter case, the halogen cyclic killing reactions may result in dysfunctions or disorders of closely interacting and communicating cell organelles, such as peroxisomes, mitochondria and lysosomes, and even severe damage to the host cells and tissues during autoimmune (over inflammation), by analogy with the severe springtime Antarctic ozone hole. The over toxicity caused by amplified RHS reactions is expected to result in unrepairable damage or mutations to cellular components, and the signalling pathways of H2O2 and NO  may be impaired as well. Disorders in these organelles can cause serious damage to multiple organs such as lung, heart, liver, kidney and nervous systems, and respiratory failure, septic shock, multi-organ failure, or even deaths. The best treatment should be in early or moderate stage or prevention.
body_text.section: Implications for the pathology of COVID19

body_text.text: Given our new understanding of the pathology of invading pathogens described above, we now discuss potential treatment of the severe virus COVID19. Exogenous halogenated aromatic ring compounds as neutral small molecules that can freely diffuse across membrane will be potent antipathogen agents. Here we present a new molecular mechanism of action (MOA) of a class of halogenated aromatic drugs such as chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine (HCQ), which have been a current focus for experimental treatment of COVID19 55-57 and more potent di-amino, di-halogen aromatic ring molecules (termed femtomedicine compounds, FMDs), which have exhibited excellent targeted chemotherapy of multiple cancers [58] [59] [60] . These drugs or candidates are promising for effective treatments of COVID19, cancer and other diseases.
body_text.section: Halogenated aromatic drugs as repurposed Drugs

body_text.text: For the MOA of HCQ and chloroquine, the readers are referred to a timing and excellent review by Schrezenmeier and Dörner 61 . As noted by the reviewers, most of the MOAs to explain the therapeutic and/or adverse effects were hypothesized based on in vitro studies, and the link between the proposed MOAs and the clinical efficacy and in vivo safety is yet to establish. The proposed molecular MOA of HCQ during autoimmunity include the following processes. Pharmacodynamic studies showed that these antimalarial drugs are lipophilic weak bases, easily cross plasma membranes, and preferentially accumulates in lysosomes, causing increases in the pH of lysosomes from 4 to 6. 62 In lysosomes, HCQ inhibits the degradation of cargos in phagolysosomes by increasing the pH to prevent the activity of lysosomal enzymes. Elevation in pH causes inhibition of lysosomal activity including diminished proteolysis effect 63 , decreased intracellular processing, glycosylation and secretion of proteins with many consequences 64 . These effects are believed to cause a decreased immune cell functioning such as chemotaxis, phagocytosis and O2 − production by neutrophils 65 .
body_text.section: Halogenated aromatic drugs as repurposed Drugs

body_text.text: Another proposed MOA was that HCQ inhibits Toll-like receptor (TLR) signalling. This speculation might be traced back to a review by Takeda et al 66 in 2003. They reviewed potent antiviral and antitumor properties of several imidazoquinolines as nucleic acid analogs, for which TLR7 was suggested to sense viral infection. Also, their unpublished data showed that two other immunomodulators, loxoribine and bropirimine, also activated immune cells through TLR7. Bropirimine (2-amin-5-bromo-6-phenyl-4(3)-pyrimidinone) is an immunomodulator that induces production of cytokines including IFN-α. It was in clinical use against renal cell carcinoma, but never got approved. There has been interest in searching TLR-activating agents for clinical use. Takeda et al 66 predicted that new therapies utilizing the TLR-mediated innate immune activation would be developed to treat several disorders such as infection, cancer, and allergy. Because of some structural similarity to these imidazoquinolines, there have been speculations that TLR7 and TLR9 receptors involve in the MOA of HCQ. However, it appears that published studies including those just reviewed 61 have not yet directly researched on this possibility.
body_text.section: Halogenated aromatic drugs as repurposed Drugs

body_text.text: Overall, available data suggest that HCQ and chloroquine impair or inhibit lysosomal and phagolysosome functions and subsequently immune activation. There are current efforts to identify exact molecular targets of HCQ within the lysosome, but convincing results and the identification of other molecular targets within the lysosomes have not yet reached. The precise molecular mechanisms of anti-pathogen effects these drugs remain essentially unknown 61 .
body_text.section: Halogenated aromatic drugs as repurposed Drugs

body_text.text: Here we propose a new molecular MOA of halogen-containing aromatic ring drugs represented by AXs, including HCQ and chloroquine, and a family of FMD compound [58] [59] [60] . Here A is a quine ring system and X=Cl for HCQ and chloroquine, whereas A is an aromatic ring coupled to two NH2 groups at ortho positions [A=B(NH2)2] and X=Cln or Brn or In with n=1,2 for FMD compounds such as 4,5-dichloro/dibromo/diiodo-1,2-diaminobenzene and 4(5)-chloro/bromo/iodo-1,2diaminobenzene 58, 59 . We propose that these molecules are highly effective for DET reactions and their action is quire similar to the formation of endogenous RHS in the phagosome. It is long known that the DET reactions of halogenated aromatic organic molecules AXs are highly effective and exothermic 18, 19, 48, 49 . The exothermic energy for the DET reaction in water is EX-D(A-X)+Ep. Here EX is the electron affinity of a X atom (ECl=3.6 eV; EBr=3.4 eV; I=3.1 eV) or the neutral radical A  (EA=~3.5 eV) 67 , D(A-X) is the bond dissociation energy [D(C-Cl)=3.5 eV; D(C-Br)=2.9 eV; D(C-I)=2.5 eV], and Ep ≈0.6 eV is the polarization energy of a halogen ion X  in water estimated from the measured redox potential of O2  (~1.0 eV) 68 . Thus, the exothermic energies for the DET reactions of AXs to form A  and X  (or A  and X  ) are estimated to be 0.7 (or 0.6), 1.1(or 1.2) and 1.2(or 1.6) eV, respectively for X=Cl, Br and I. These calculated data indicate that the DET reactions of AXs with weakly-bound electrons in water can effectively take place in phagolysosome, as shown in Fig. 4 .
body_text.section: New molecular mechanism of action (MOA) of halogenated aromatic drugs

body_text.text: Similar to the DET reactions of endogenous halogenated organic compounds, effective DET reactions of AXs can occur with the enzymes such as MPO/EPO/LPO/SOD or NADPH:
body_text.section: New molecular mechanism of action (MOA) of halogenated aromatic drugs

body_text.text: In addition, DET reactions of AXs with O2  can also occur with or without the involvement of enzymes in the phagolysosome. This is especially effective for brominated and iodized aromatic molecules as their DET reactions have larger exothermicities: Correspondingly, Br  and I  atoms can most effectively be generated and have highly effective reaction cycles to amplify the biological effects. The formed reactive radical AO2  can also directly cause damaging effects, e.g., by hydrogen abstraction from DNA/RNA, lipids or proteins, while X − like endogenous halogen ions can be converted into HOX, OX  , X  and X2 via the enzymes. Like endogenous HOCl/HOBr/HOI, these exogenous RHS will have the amplifying cyclic reactions and cause significant anti-pathogen effects for immunological defence.
body_text.section: New molecular mechanism of action (MOA) of halogenated aromatic drugs

body_text.text: As observed for HCQ, these neutral small-molecule AXs including FMDs can easily cross plasma membranes to accumulate in lysosomes. We propose that the MOA of HCQ or chloroquine should be due to the enhanced pathogen-killing effect induced by the reaction cycles of RHS derived from the DET of the drug. Indeed, the DET reaction of these molecules will lead to an increase in the radical A  or X  yield (a decrease in OH − as the reaction A  /X  + OH −  OH + A − /X − is highly exothermic by ~1.7 eV) in lysosomes, i.e., equivalent to a rise in pH, consistent with the observations. When there are invading pathogens in early or intermediate stages, pathogens are effectively killed in the formed phagolysosomes with excess RHS before autoimmune occurs. Since the DET reaction efficiencies are expected to increase in the order of Cl<Br<I for X in AXs, as we already observed for halopyrimidines (CldU, BrdU, IdU) 48, 49 , and more critically the DET reactions of Br-and I-containing aromatic ring molecules can readily produce Br  or I  atoms to activate cycle 2 reactions, the in vivo therapeutic efficacy should increase in the order of ACln<<ABrn<AIn (n=1,2).
body_text.section: Potential new therapeutics

body_text.text: As for anti-cancer activity of AXs, similar RHS are expected to be generated and to cause cellular killing. Moreover, since both H2O2 and NO are neutral small signaling molecules that can diffuse freely across the membrane and have high mobility, similar reaction cycles of RHS are expected to take place in other intracellular organelles such as mitochondria and peroxisomes which are electron (antioxidant)-rich. Indeed, our in vitro and in vivo experimental results of multiple cancers have confirmed that the therapeutic efficacies of FMDs increases in the order of ACl2<<ABr2<AI2 58, 59 . Moreover, our unpublished data 69 by direct, real-time femtosecond laser spectroscopic measurements have confirmed the highly effective DET reactions of FMDs.
body_text.section: Potential new therapeutics

body_text.text: Notably, FMD compounds distinguish themselves from other drugs such as HCQ and chloroquine, bropirimine, BrdU and IdU, not only by yielding highly reactive Br  or I  atoms to initiate the powerful H2O2-independent reaction cycles but by a unique structural characteristic that contains two NH2 groups attached to the ring system at ortho positions. This idea is based on a previous surprising finding that the presence of ammonia can cause giant enhancements in the DET reaction efficacies of CFCs adsorbed on ice surfaces by up to 30000 times 16, 45 , which was later confirmed by others 51 (for reviews, see refs. 18 and 19) . Although in vivo DET efficiencies may not be enhanced to this extent, there is every reason to expect that the DET reactions of FMDs should be at least 10 times more effective than any other halogenated organic molecules without the two neighboring NH2 groups in their structures. This was indeed observed by comparing the DET reactions of FMDs with BrdU and IdU 69 . BrdU is very similar to bropirimine in structure 66 . Thus, we predict that the in vivo anti-pathogen effectiveness of FMDs with proper formulations will be at least 10 times higher than that of any of HCQ, chloroquine, bropirimine, BrdU and IdU.
body_text.section: Potential new therapeutics

body_text.text: Of particular interesting is also the finding that in treated normal cells, a FMD at 100 M caused an increase by about 40% of the reduced glutathione (GSH) level, which is an endogenous protective antioxidant, whereas the GSH level in human cervical (ME-180) cancer cells significantly dropped upon treated by the FMD and decreased to ~35% at 100 M FMD 58 . This marked selective depletion of the GSH was consistent with the proposed preferential DET reaction to activate in cancer cells and with the observed selective cytotoxic effects of FMDs in vitro and in vivo [58] [59] [60] . These results showed that FMDs even have a protective effect on normal cells while killing abnormal cells and can be used as targeted chemotherapeutic agents 70 .
body_text.section: Potential new therapeutics

body_text.text: Although no tests on antiviral activity of FMDs have been performed, our new studies on animal cancer models have shown that FMDs such as 4,5-dibromo-1,2-diaminobenzene and 4,5diiodo-1,2-diaminobenzene at doses of ≤35 mg/kg (i.p) showed a superior efficacy in anti-cancer activity (leading to significant tumor shrinkage) to the clinical drugs such as cisplatin and gemcitabine at doses that showed significant toxic side effects. In contrast, the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of 4,5-dibromo-1,2-diaminobenzene was measured to be 24025 mg/kg (i.p), and no significant multiple dose toxicity in blood, liver, kidney, gut and spleen for 90 mg/kg/week for 4 weeks in mice (i.v) were observed. The oral MTD, which is usually at least 5 times higher, may be over 1000 mg/kg. These results indicate that FMDs are essentially non-toxic but highly effective chemotherapeutic agents at used doses that can preferentially kill abnormal cells. It is therefore useful for natural targeted chemotherapy of cancer and other diseases, which potentially include viral infections and autoimmune disorders. By contrast, due to the increased risk of developing retinopathy during treatment with HCQ, the current ophthalmology guidelines recommend a maximal daily dose of 5.0 mg/kg (actual body weight) per day for HCQ, while in cancer studies, high HCQ doses up to 1,200 mg (17-18 mg/kg) daily was prescribed 71, 61 . Given these data, FMDs are estimated to have a clinical safe dose at least 10 times higher than HCQ in humans. Thus, FMDs at a wide non-toxic dose range have high potential to outperform over existing drugs such as chloroquine and HCQ that have known toxic side effects.
body_text.section: Potential new therapeutics

body_text.text: During the revision of this manuscript, Caly et al. 72 report that the FDA-approved ivermectin inhibits replication of SARS-CoV-2 in vitro, making it a possible candidate for COVID19 drug repurposing research. Interestingly, pharmacological studies showed that the drug binds to glutamate-gated chloride channels (GluCls, present in neurons and myocytes) in the membranes of invertebrate nerve and muscle cells, causing increased permeability to Cl − ions, resulting in cellular hyper-polarization, followed by paralysis and death. The pathology proposed in this paper can well explain the MOA of this drug: the increased Cl − permeability will elevate the Cl − level and the associated RHS cyclic reactions to enhance the pathogen-killing effects.
body_text.section: Potential new therapeutics

body_text.text: Provided with the pathology of infection and molecular MOA of drugs proposed in this paper, drugs (candidates) like HCQ and FMDs will enhance rather than inhibit the endogenous pathogenkilling effect in the immune system in humans. These halogenated aromatic drugs or candidates should be encouraged and recommended for experimental treatment of COVID19, especially for preventive, mild and moderate stages, and probably treatment of developed chronic conditions. In these applications, the halogen compounds should provide strong pathogen-killing effects. During autoimmune, however, precaution should be taken if these drugs are to be used, because they will produce an excess number of exogenous RHS, much larger than that of endogenous RHS. In the latter case, using a NO (iNOS) inducer to enhance the production of the electron killer (NO3 − / CO3 − ) neutralizing RHS might be helpful to the patients. This paper provides a plausible molecular mechanism that might help the clinical practice of the drugs. It can improve the clinical efficacy, control the toxicity within a tolerated range, and suggest the optimal timing/sequential administration or possible combination therapy. This might meet the current medical challenges faced in this global pandemic and save many lives across the globe. Furthermore, this research also reveals that H2O2 is a necessary signaling molecules (angel) in the defense system fighting against pathogens and maintaining normal physiological functioning and signaling and its dysfunction can cause many diseases of plants to humans. The role of innate immune defense is probably underestimated under current context of immunology and virology. The new mechanistic insights into the immune defense might lead to discovery and development of more potent and/or targeted drugs for treatment of many diseases such as virus infection, cancer and others.

FIGREF1.text: Fig. 2. Proposed halogen reaction cycles involved in the immune defense against pathogens and in the inflammatory process. The amplified reactions of reactive halogen species (RHS), including HOX, OX − , X 2 , X • and OX • (X=Cl, Br or I), produced by dissociative electron transfer (DET) within the phagosome cause major damage (represented by RX/RNX) to the DNA/RNA/lipids/proteins of phagocytosed pathogens. The innate immune defence system consists mainly of three components: the H 2 O 2 signaling pathway as the activator ('trigger'), the RHS reaction cycles as the 'accelerator' ('amplifier'), and the NO • signaling pathway as the deactivator ('terminator'). H 2 O 2 from other intracellular organelles such as mitochondria and peroxisomes can also diffuse across membranes and promote the anti-pathogen activity.

For HCQ and chloroquine, A is a quine ring system and X=Cl, whereas A is an aromatic ring coupled to two NH 2 groups at ortho positions [A=B(NH 2 ) 2 ] and X=Cl n or Br n or I n with n=1,2 for FMD compounds)58,59 .

Reactive oxygen/halogen/nitrogen species (OH • ; HOX with X=Cl, Br or I; NO 2 ) produced within the phagosome cause damage to the DNA/RNA/lipids/proteins of phagocytosed pathogens. Growth factors, cytokines, and integrins stimulate the activation of NADPH oxidase to form O 2 − . H 2 O 2 can also be produced extracellularly by the IgG-catalyzed oxidation of water or by receptor/ligand interactions.
